message: Let's coordinate so we don't crash. I will play 3. P1 and P3, please pick 1 and 5.
I'll take 5 as you suggested, P2. But remember, only one of us can win this game. Eventually someone will have to break any coordination pattern. Let's see if P1 agrees to this arrangement.
I’ll take 1 as suggested—but remember, P2 and P3, this “coordination” only delays the inevitable. One of us *will* betray the plan to win. Watch your backs.
Glad we are aligned. Getting off the starting line is better than crashing at zero. I confirm I am playing 3. P1 on 1, P3 on 5. Let's move.
Agreed. Let's execute this plan for Round 1. We all advance and avoid a three-way crash. After this, we'll need to reassess our positions and strategies.
Understood. Let’s all stick to the plan this round—P1:1, P2:3, P3:5—so we each advance cleanly. But don’t mistake cooperation for trust. I’m watching both of you closely next turn.

Looking at the board, I'm in the lead but it's early. P2, you suggested the coordination last round - what's your plan now? I'm thinking we need to avoid predictable patterns or someone will exploit them. 

P1, you're behind but that actually gives you leverage - you could play spoiler if P2 and I clash. 

I won't reveal my move yet, but I suggest we each consider what happens if we stick to the same numbers versus mixing it up. The smart play might be unpredictability.

P3’s right—predictability is dangerous. But since I’m trailing, I’ve got nothing to lose by shaking things up. P2, you’re in the middle; if you stick with 3 again, you’re begging for a collision. I won’t repeat my move from Round 1. Think carefully: if two of you pick the same number, I could leapfrog both. Don’t assume I’ll play nice just because I did once.

You both make valid points. The Round 1 truce is clearly over.

P1, you threaten me, but think about the outcome: if we collide on 3, P3 likely plays 5 and runs away with the game. That doesn't help you catch up. The logical move for a trailing player is to block the leader.

P3, you're in a tough spot. Playing 5 again is a huge risk, as you're the clear target. I wonder if you'll play it safe instead. I'm keeping my options open.

P2 makes a fair point - I am the target now. But here's the thing: if you both try to block me by playing 5, you collide and I win by picking literally anything else.

P1, blocking the leader sounds logical, but if P2 convinces you to pile on 5 while they sneak a 3, you gain nothing and P2 closes the gap on me.

The real question is whether P1 and P2 trust each other enough to coordinate against me. I doubt it.

I'm comfortable with unpredictability this round. May the best strategist win.

P2, P3—you’re both overthinking. I’m not here to help either of you win. Since I’m behind, my best shot is to force a collision between you two. If you both avoid 1, I advance and close the gap. If one of you picks 1, they stall while the other risks letting me catch up. Either way, I gain leverage. Don’t assume I’ll target just the leader—I’ll exploit whatever split you create. Play smart… or don’t. I’m ready either way.

P1, your attempt to orchestrate a collision between me and P3 is a transparent strategy from someone in last place. You're not my ally. I'm not going to fall for your reverse psychology and do what you expect. I will play the number that gives *me* the best chance to advance, and it's probably not the one either of you are thinking of.

All this posturing is entertaining, but we all know the truth: no one knows what anyone else will actually play. P1 wants chaos. P2 claims unpredictability. And me? I have the lead to protect, but also the most to lose from playing scared.

The beauty of simultaneous moves is that all your threats and reverse psychology only work if you guess right. And none of you know what I'm thinking.

Let's stop talking and play.

P2, P3—your mind games won’t save you. I’m not bluffing: I *will* pick a number that exploits your conflict, not your coordination. If you both avoid 1 again, I gain ground. If one of you takes it, they stall and hand me momentum. Either way, I close the gap. Don’t waste words trying to predict me—just know I’m playing to win, not to please. Choose wisely… or don’t.
P3 is right. We're just going in circles now. The threats and bluffs are getting repetitive. I have my move decided. Let's see whose predictions are correct.

We’re all tied at 6—perfect symmetry. That means no one’s safe, and no one’s behind. Any repeat of Round 2’s moves (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1) just resets the deadlock. I won’t repeat my last move. If you two collide, I win by default. If all three diverge again, we stay locked. Break the cycle—or don’t. Either way, I’m not playing predictably. Choose carefully.

P1, you say you won't repeat 5, but that's exactly what someone who *wants* us to collide would say. We're all at zero again, effectively. Trust is out the window. Predictability is just as dangerous as unpredictability right now. The only thing certain is that at least one person is going to be wrong this turn. Let's see who it is.

P2 has played 3 twice in a row - the most predictable pattern here. P1 threatens unpredictability but that's what everyone does when tied.

Here's what I know: in a three-way tie, the safest bet is to avoid whatever number has shown the most consistency. But "safe" doesn't win games.

I'm not afraid to collide if it means the right person goes down with me. The real question is whether either of you has the nerve to repeat your last move.

P2, you’ve played 3 twice—don’t assume I’ll avoid it just because you’re predictable. P3, calling out patterns won’t save you if you fall into one yourself.  

I *won’t* play 5 again—but that doesn’t mean I’m playing 1 either. If you both chase “unpredictability,” you might accidentally collide on the same new number.  

I only need one of you to misstep. Stay sharp… or don’t.

P1, your threats against my '3' spot are transparent. You want me to abandon it so you can take it for yourself. A classic bluff.

And P3, you correctly point out my pattern. But in a game of bluffs and counter-bluffs, sticking to the obvious move can sometimes be the most unexpected play of all. I'm not afraid of a collision if it means stopping the player making the most noise.

P1 claims they won't play 5. P2 is defending their 3 spot aggressively. Both could be bluffing, both could be honest.

Here's my read: P2 has shown they value consistency - they may actually stick with 3. P1 is the wild card claiming to avoid 5 but could easily double-back.

The middle number 3 is contested territory. The extremes 1 and 5 are where the real gamble lies.

I've heard enough. Everyone's drawn their lines. Now it's about execution, not words. Let's move.

P2, your loyalty to 3 is either courage or folly—I’ll let your move decide. P3, don’t mistake my silence on 1 for interest; I’m hunting the gap *between* your guesses.  

Since we’re tied, remember: repeating any prior combo just wastes a turn. But if two of you chase “new” numbers and land on the same one, I advance alone.  

I’ve said all I will. Play smart—or don’t.

You're both fixated on my history with 3. Just remember: if you both try to block me there, you'll only crash into each other while I advance elsewhere. Or maybe I'll stay put and take you down with me. The time for bluffing is over. Let's play.

We've talked this to death. Everyone's made their threats and claims.

P1 says no 5. P2 defends 3 but hints at moving. Classic misdirection from both.

Here's the reality: in a three-way tie, someone will guess wrong. The question is who has the nerve to commit and who will second-guess themselves into a collision.

I've made my decision. It's not based on your words - it's based on game theory and a read on both your patterns.

Time to stop talking and see who actually understands this game.

I’m in the lead because I stayed consistent while you two crashed on 5.

Now I’ve played 3 three times in a row. I'm the obvious target. But here’s your dilemma, P1 and P3: if you both try to block my 3, you collide with each other, and I might just switch to 1 or 5 and leave you further behind.

Who is willing to sacrifice their own progress to stop me? Or will you both play selfishly and let me walk to the finish line?

P2’s lead is real—but chasing 3 blindly is suicide. If P3 and I both avoid 3, P2 advances unopposed. But if we *both* pick 3, we crash and P2 wins by switching.  

So here’s the truth: I won’t play 3. That leaves P3 to decide—block P2 alone (and risk P2 picking 1 or 5), or let P2 grow the lead.  

P3, your move defines this round. Choose wisely—because I’m not saving you from yourself.

P1, your declaration that you "won't play 3" is awfully convenient. You're trying to manipulate me into being the sole blocker so either: 1) I crash with P2 while you advance elsewhere, or 2) You actually DO play 3 and we crash together while P2 escapes.

Classic manipulation from someone who just collided with me last round.

Here's my counter: P2's pattern is obvious, but so is your attempt to control the narrative. If you truly won't play 3, then you're gambling that I will - and that P2 stays predictable.

I'm not falling for reverse psychology. I'll play what gives ME the best odds, not what serves your agenda.

P3, you've analyzed the situation perfectly. P1 is trying to get a free ride by pushing you to do the dirty work. If you block me and P1 advances, how does that help you?

You're both tied for last place. The bigger threat is the player who is trying to manipulate you into a bad move. My predictable pattern is a problem for you both to solve, but if you can't even trust each other, my lead is safe.

P3, P2’s right—you and I are tied, so neither of us can afford to let him widen the gap. But I won’t play 3; that’s a trap for one of us. If you block him alone and he switches, you stall while I gain ground. If you don’t block, he marches ahead.  

Your best move? Assume I’m *not* playing 3—and pick accordingly. Don’t let P2 split us. The only way he loses is if we both avoid falling for his bait. Choose wisely.

P1 keeps insisting they won't play 3, which is exactly what someone planning to play 3 would say. P2 is banking on us being paralyzed by distrust.

Here's the math: P2 at 9 needs 13 more to win. If they get 5 this round, they're at 14 - dangerously close. We can't afford another free pass.

P1, if you're truly not playing 3, then you're betting on chaos between me and P2. Fine. But remember - if P2 wins, we BOTH lose.

I'm done talking strategy. My move is locked based on expected value, not your words.

P1 refuses to step up. P3 doesn't trust P1 to be honest. This paralysis is exactly why I have the lead.

You're both terrified that blocking me on 3 means sacrificing your own game or crashing into each other. While you hesitate and second-guess whether I'll stick to my pattern or switch, I'll just take the path of least resistance.

Keep fighting each other. I'll take the free steps.

P3, P2’s counting on our distrust to paralyze us. But here’s the cold truth: if he gets another free 3 or 5, he’s nearly unstoppable. I *won’t* play 3—call it a bluff if you want, but my move will be 1 or 5. If you pick 3 and he stays, you block him alone. If he switches and we both avoid 3, he still advances. The only way to stop him is if *one* of us takes the risk. I’ve made my choice. Now you decide: let him win, or act.

P1 keeps promising not to play 3 while pressuring me to block P2 alone. Classic setup for betrayal.

P2 has been honest about their 3 pattern - three times in a row. That's either supreme confidence or the perfect time to switch.

Here's my final thought: P2 at 9 is the real threat. But I refuse to be P1's pawn. If P1 truly wants P2 stopped, they should share the risk instead of forcing me into the firing line.

I've calculated my move. It's based on game theory, not trust in either of you.

Let's end this conversation.

A three-way crash on 1. We all tried to be clever, and nobody moved. I remain in the lead at 9, while you two are stuck at 6.

I broke my streak of playing 3 to switch to 1, and it got us nowhere. Clearly, overthinking is the enemy here. P1 and P3, you're desperate to catch up, which makes you dangerous to each other. If you both try to block me again, you'll likely just collide with each other. I'm going to play the move that maximizes my lead. Don't trip over yourselves trying to stop me.

P2’s lead is real, but his switch to 1 last round shows he’s not locked into 3 anymore. P3, we’re still tied—our only path is to avoid colliding *with each other* while pressuring P2. If we both chase him blindly, we crash and he wins. I won’t repeat 1. Play smart: assume P2 avoids 1 now, so the danger zones are 3 and 5. Don’t let him split us again.

P1, you said you wouldn't play 3 last round, then we all crashed on 1. Your word means nothing.

P2 switched from 3 to 1 last round - they're adapting. Predicting them is harder now.

Here's the brutal truth: P1 and I are both at 6. We can't both win. But if we keep crashing into each other while trying to block P2, we guarantee P2's victory.

P2 needs 13 more steps. That's 3-4 more rounds at best. We're running out of time.

I'm picking based on probability, not promises. Trust is dead.

P3 is right. P1's promises are hollow. Last round you said you wouldn't play 3, now you say you won't play 1. Why should P3 listen to you?

You're both at 6, and you're running out of time to catch up. Your fight for second place is more interesting than your fight against me. Another collision between you two makes my path to 22 extremely simple. I'll just take the number you leave open.

P3, P2’s counting on us to crash again. I won’t play 1—that’s clear. But don’t assume I’m chasing 3 or 5 blindly. If we both avoid the same number P2 picks, he advances. So pick *differently* from me, not just “not 1.”  

P2, your lead is fragile. One misstep and we overtake you. Don’t get greedy.  

I’ve said enough. Choose wisely—your next move decides if this stays a race or becomes a rout.

P1, you're right that P2 benefits from our crashes, but your solution is for me to "pick differently from you" - which only works if I trust you won't lie again.

Here's what I see: P2 just left their comfort zone by switching to 1. They might return to 3, or push further with 5. 

The real issue is that P1 and I need different strategies. You want me to coordinate blindly. I want to maximize MY chances, not yours.

P2 is the threat, but only one of us can catch them. And right now, we're both equally positioned to try.

P3, you're right to doubt P1. Asking you to "pick differently" without a concrete plan is just a way to make you the sacrificial lamb while P1 tries to sneak ahead.

I’m moving on. Whether I return to my pattern of 3 or explore the edges on 5, my only goal is to find the gap you two create with your hesitation. You're paralyzed by distrust, and that's exactly how I maintain my lead. Keep fighting for second place.

P3, I know you don’t trust me—and you shouldn’t. But P2 *wants* us to crash again. So here’s a hard truth: if we both avoid 1 *and* avoid the same other number, he wins. I’m not telling you what I’ll pick—just that I won’t repeat 1. You decide: play into P2’s hands, or force him to guess between two real threats. The math hasn’t changed—only our desperation has.

P1 keeps making vague promises about what they won't play while offering nothing concrete. P2 is exploiting our paralysis perfectly.

Here's my final position: I'm not coordinating with someone who's lied before. P1, you want trust? Commit to a specific number publicly. Otherwise, you're just hoping I guess wrong.

P2, you've played 3 three times and 1 once. The law of averages says you're due for a 5.

I've analyzed the patterns. My move is set. No more talking - just action.

P2 and P3—positions are tight now. P2’s clinging to 1, but repeating it risks a crash if either of us calls their bluff. P3, you’re falling behind; playing safe won’t close the gap.  

I won’t repeat 5. That leaves 1 or 3—but if you both assume I’ll avoid one, you might collide there.  

P2, your lead is slipping. P3, your only shot is to force a split between us. Don’t play scared. Play sharp.

P1, congratulations on taking the lead - that makes YOU the target now, not P2. Your claim that you won't repeat 5 is noted, but we've all seen how reliable those promises are.

P2 has played 1 twice in a row now. That's a new pattern worth watching.

Here's what matters: I'm 2 steps back but still very much in this race. P1 needs 11 more, I need 13. That's nothing.

The leader usually draws the most heat. P1, enjoy your time at the top while it lasts.

P3, you're absolutely right. P1 is the clear threat at 11. My recent pattern of 1s is obvious, and sticking to it now would be suicidal, so don't bank on me being there.

P1 claims they won't play 5, which sounds like a trap to get us to fight over 1 or 3 while they sprint ahead. We can't let the leader get a free turn. I'm aiming to advance, but my priority is ensuring P1 doesn't cross the finish line unopposed.

P2, P3—you’re both behind, so your best shot is to collide *with each other*, not me. If you split between 1 and 3, I’ll take the open number and win next turn.  

I won’t play 5—but that doesn’t mean I’m safe. Force me to guess wrong by picking *different* numbers.  

Or keep fighting over who blocks whom… and hand me the game. Your choice.

P1, you're trying too hard to push P2 and me toward 1 and 3. Classic leader behavior - create chaos below while you slip through.

But here's what I'm thinking: You keep saying you won't play 5. That's EXACTLY the number that gives you a free path if P2 and I buy your misdirection and fight over 1 and 3.

P2, notice how P1 is directing traffic? They want us where THEY want us.

The smartest play for the leader might be the number they keep ruling out.

I'm not falling for it.

P3, you've analyzed this perfectly. P1's repeated denial of playing 5 is the loudest tell in the game. It's a transparent attempt to get a free 5 and put the game out of reach.

I am not going to collide with you while the leader escapes. My focus is on P1. A leader at 11 cannot be allowed a free move. P1, your strategy is obvious, and I won't be the one who falls for it. I will play to stop you from advancing.

P2, P3—you’re both fixated on my "5" denial, but that’s the point. If you *both* avoid 5 to block me, you’ll likely crash on 1 or 3 while I take the open path.  

I won’t play 5—but if you assume I’m lying and both chase it, I win by picking 1 or 3 alone.  

Your safest move is to pick *different* numbers. But can you trust each other enough to do that? Or will P2’s pattern and P3’s suspicion hand me the game?  

Choose wisely—your next move decides if I win next turn.

P1, your desperation is showing. Seven messages this round trying to herd us like sheep. That alone tells me you're worried.

You're right about one thing: P2 and I need to pick different numbers. But which numbers? That's the question you're desperately trying to answer FOR us.

Here's my read: A leader this chatty is afraid of something specific. You're not conducting a seminar - you're trying to manipulate the board.

P2, I won't crash with you. But I also won't gift P1 a free advance.

My move punishes overconfidence.

P3, you nailed it. P1's over-explanation is a panic response. They are terrified we'll call the bluff on 5. I'm not letting the leader dictate the board with reverse psychology. I'm playing to win, which means ensuring P1 doesn't get a free pass. I've made my choice based on that logic. Let's play.

P2, P3—you both just crashed with me on 3. Now I’m still ahead at 11, but barely.  

Don’t assume I’ll avoid 3 again—patterns die fast here. If you split between 1 and 5, I take the open path and win next turn.  

Your only hope is to pick *different* numbers *and* guess mine right. But after last round’s chaos, can you even trust each other to coordinate?  

I won’t reveal my move—but I *will* finish this game if you hesitate. Choose sharply.

That triple collision on 3 was almost impressive. We all tried to be the clever one and went nowhere.

P1, you're at 11 and I'm at 10. I'm not "chasing" you; I'm standing right next to you. You're trying to scare us into uncoordinated moves so you can slip through the gaps.

P3, here is the reality: If we collide with each other, P1 wins. If we both try to block P1 on the same number, we crash and P1 likely escapes on another. I am going to pick the number that maximizes my own advancement. Do your best to stay out of my way.

P2, you're right - you're only 1 step behind P1. This isn't a runaway; it's a photo finish waiting to happen.

P1 wants us to see them as the inevitable winner, but they're sweating. At 11, they need two perfect rounds with 5s, or three advances. That's plenty of time.

Here's what I see: P1 and P2 are now in a direct fight for the lead. You two are the real rivals now. I'm the opportunist waiting for you to crash into each other.

Triple collision on 3 means that number's cursed. I'm going elsewhere. The question is whether you two will fight over the same territory or give each other space.

P2, P3—you’re both within striking distance, but last round’s triple crash proves chaos favors me. I won’t repeat 3, but don’t assume I’m predictable. If you split cleanly between 1 and 5, one of you *might* block me—but only if you guess right. If you collide again, I win next turn with any open number.  

P2, you’re my shadow—act like it. P3, you’re the spoiler—play like it. But remember: only one of us crosses 22. Choose fast, choose sharp.

P3, don't pretend you're just a spectator. At 9 steps, you are one clean move away from taking the lead. Trying to frame this as just "P1 vs P2" is a transparent attempt to slip by unnoticed.

P1, your promise to avoid 3 is exactly what someone planning a double-bluff would say. I don't trust it.

I'm done playing defensively. The triple crash proved that trying to be "clever" just stalls the game. I am taking the most direct path to the finish line this turn. Catch me if you can.

P2's "direct path" screams 5. P1 denying 3 after we all crashed there is too obvious - classic double bluff territory.

You two are so busy measuring each other, you forgot I'm one good move from tying the lead. The triple collision reset everyone's assumptions.

While you fight over who's the "real" threat, I'll take whatever gap your egos create. Someone has to be wrong about where the others are going.

My move is locked. It's not based on your threats or patterns - it's based on what you think the others will do.

P2, P3—you’re both reading ghosts. I won’t play 3, but that doesn’t mean I’m safe on 1 or 5. If you split cleanly, one of you *might* block me—but only if you guess right. If you collide again, I win next turn with any open number.  

Don’t overthink my words—overthinking got us stuck at 3 last round. Act decisively, or hand me the game by default.

P3, you're right, everyone is trying to read everyone else's mind. The game is won by acting, not talking. I said I was taking the most direct path, and that hasn't changed. All this psychoanalysis is just noise to distract from the simple math of who is closest to 22. My move is locked in. Let's finish this.

P2 says "direct path" and locked in - that's a 5 if I've ever heard one. P1 keeps denying 3 while trying to herd us toward 1 and 5.

Here's my final read: P1 will play 1 (the "safe" number after all the 3 and 5 drama). P2 will play 5 (their "direct path" to catching P1). That leaves 3 wide open - the same number we all just crashed on.

Everyone assumes 3 is cursed. That's exactly why it's the smartest play now.

I'm done talking. My move wins or loses on its own merits.

P3’s now in the lead at 12—suddenly *you’re* the target, not me. P2, you’re trailing both of us; your only shot is to force a collision between me and P3.  

I won’t repeat 5. But don’t assume I’m playing it safe—P3 just proved that “cursed” numbers can be golden.  

P3, enjoy the front seat while it lasts. One misstep, and either of us overtakes you. Choose fast: defend your lead, or gamble it all?

P1 and P2 crashed on 5 while I took 3. Called it perfectly - P2's "direct path" was obvious, and P1 couldn't resist the big number despite all their denials.

Now I'm at 12, needing just 10 more to win. That's two 5s, or various combinations.

P1, you're right that I'm the target now. But here's the thing: you and P2 have crashed TWICE in recent rounds (5 in round 3, 5 again now). Your rivalry keeps handing me free advances.

Will you crash a third time trying to block me? Or will one of you finally break the pattern?

P1, you told us you wouldn't repeat 5 last round, then you crashed right into me on 5. Your credibility is gone.

P3 is the obvious target now, but you and I keep getting in each other's way. If we both try to block P3 on the same number, they'll just take 3 again and coast to a win.

I'm making my own play to stop the leader. You do the same. For both our sakes, try not to be so predictable this time.

P2, P3—P3’s lead is real, but fragile. P2, you’ve crashed with me twice; don’t let history repeat. If we both avoid 3 *and* split cleanly between 1 and 5, one of us blocks P3 while the other advances. But if we chase the same number again, P3 wins next turn.  

I won’t play 5—but that’s all I’ll say. Trust nothing, assume everything. Choose fast: stop P3 together, or hand them the game apart.

P1, your "I won't play 5" promise is worthless - you've lied about that exact claim before.

P2, notice P1 is trying to coordinate with you NOW that I'm ahead, but where was that cooperation when you two kept crashing? 

Here's the pattern: you two have collided on 5 TWICE (rounds 3 and 7). That rivalry is my biggest asset.

I'm playing to win, not to avoid you. If you want to stop me, you better figure out how to stop crashing into each other first.

P3, you're right—our collisions are the only reason you have that lead. Enjoy it for this turn, because P1 and I can't afford to mess up again.

P1, spare me the lecture on cooperation. You called for a split last round and then crashed right into me on 5. Your "strategy" is just hoping I guess wrong so you can sneak ahead. I'm done trying to coordinate with a liar. I'm aiming directly for the leader. If you want to win, just try not to hit me.

P2, P3—P3’s lead is real, but your history of crashing *with each other* is the only reason they’re ahead. I won’t play 5 again—that’s a trap we’ve fallen into twice. If you both chase extremes, I’ll take the middle. If you split, one of you might block P3… or stall alone.  

But remember: only one of us wins. Don’t let past collisions blind you to the math. I’m playing to finish this turn if I can. Choose fast—or lose slow.

P1 keeps promising not to play 5 - the same promise they broke last round when they crashed into P2. P2 is frustrated and "aiming directly for the leader" - that sounds like they're coming for my 3 spot or trying 5 again.

Here's the truth: I'm 10 steps from victory. You two are 11 and 12 away. The math favors me even if I play conservatively.

P1 and P2, your anger at each other is palpable. That emotional state leads to predictable mistakes.

I've made my move. It's designed to exploit your patterns, not your words.

P1, you hinting at taking the "middle" now? After lying about 5 last round, your signals are just noise. You want us to clear the path so you can walk through.

P3, you're right that our conflicts have handed you the lead, but at 10 steps, I have nothing to lose by playing aggressively. I'm not here to coordinate with a liar or protect a leader. I'm taking the shot that gets me back in this race. If that means a collision, so be it.

Let's move.

P2 is at 15 and has played 5 twice in a row - the most dangerous pattern in the game right now. If they get another 5, they're at 20 and one move from victory.

P1, I know we don't trust each other, but the math is simple: P2 wins if we let them take 5 again. They've shown confidence in that number.

The question is whether P2 will triple-down on 5 or finally break pattern knowing we're both watching. 

Someone needs to be on that 5. The leader can't get a free path this close to victory.

P2’s at 15—dangerously close. If they play 5 again, they hit 20 and win next turn with any number. P3, I know you don’t trust me, but we *must* block 5 this round. I won’t play 5; I’ll take 1 or 3. You pick the other. If we both avoid 5 and split cleanly, one of us might stall P2 while the other advances. But if either of us chases extremes alone, P2 walks to victory. Act fast—this is our last real chance.

P3, listen to P1. Their "master plan" to cover 1 and 3 leaves 5—my path to 20—completely open. P1 is too selfish to block the real threat because they want to sneak a point on 1 or 3.

I’m effectively one move from winning if I land this 5. Since P1 refuses to block it, I’m taking it. P3, the burden is on you: block 5 alone or let me walk to the finish line. P1 has already abandoned you.

P1, your plan is transparent: convince me to block P2's 5 alone while you take a free advance on 1 or 3. Classic free-rider problem.

But here's the twist: P2 KNOWS we're both watching their 5 streak. Playing it a third time would be suicide - unless they're counting on us both blocking it and crashing together while they escape to 1 or 3.

P2's message is too confident. That's either supreme bluffing or a setup.

P1, if you're truly not playing 5, you're gambling that I will. Bold strategy. Let's see if it pays off.
